summary: Thomas Howarth is identified as an employee of the House Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA). The documents mentioning him primarily consist of payroll authorization forms and related memoranda detailing his salary and position changes within the HSCA from 1976 to 1978. The documents do not provide specific details about his role in the JFK assassination investigation, but they confirm his employment during the period when the HSCA was actively investigating the assassination. The documents related to Howarth are part of a larger collection of HSCA staff payroll records, many of which include notifications from the Assassination Records Review Board regarding the postponement of Social Security number releases to protect personal privacy.
significance: Thomas Howarth's significance lies in his employment with the HSCA during its investigation of the JFK assassination. While the documents do not specify his direct involvement in the investigation, his payroll records provide evidence of the staffing and operations of the HSCA during this period. The documents contribute to the broader historical record of the HSCA's activities and personnel.
